image.altText: Earth surrounded by junk

items.synopsis: Fragments of spent rockets and other debris are clogging up the area above the stratosphere. As tensions ratchet up on Earth, some space agencies fear the next frontier of conflict could be above us.

title.children: Could 'unusual and disturbing' behaviour in space unleash a new frontier in war?

image.altText: A stack of surfboards near 'The Spot' on West Island at the Cocos Keeling Islands.

items.synopsis: The Defence Force is about to splash more than $500 million on this remote part of Australia to upgrade the airstrip to take more high-tech spy planes. Locals, already concerned about parts of the islands falling into the sea, are worried what it'll mean for their futures.

title.children: These 'inconvenient Australians' fear their slice of paradise will be ruined in the name of national security

image.altText: A gas flare

items.synopsis: Government and industry say gas is needed to fill the gaps as the state transitions to renewables, as climate scientists push for "smart and clean" over "dumb and dirty".

title.children: Woodside, Chevron say WA faces gas supply crunch as scientists warn of 'climate time bomb'

image.altText: 2008-01-16T120000Z_1761576427_GM1DXBBLHZAA_RTRMADP_3_BRITAIN-DIANA

items.synopsis: The self-made Egyptian billionaire, who owned London's luxury Harrods department store, spent 10 years trying to prove Princess Diana and his son Dodi were murdered when their car crashed in a Paris road tunnel in 1997.

title.children: Former Harrods owner Mohamed al-Fayed dies at 94

image.altText: Television presenter David Attenborough

items.synopsis: When David Attenborough was touring China in 1979, he asked a question about population control. Transcripts show it was one of the first mentions of the One Child Policy to Western media.

title.children: One of China's biggest decisions was a secret from the West. Then David Attenborough asked one question

image.altText: A man in a turban takes a selfie in front of an Alice Springs sign.

items.synopsis: Grassroots initiatives are proving "powerful" to help multicultural Australians decide how to vote in the Voice referendum. And now a date is set, individuals and independent groups are going to great lengths to ensure their communities are informed.

title.children: Grassroots efforts may be the 'powerful' decider for multicultural Australians' Voice vote

image.altText: An illustration of a giant red creature with grey tentacles walking along a street.

items.synopsis: Tan has won numerous awards and two of his books, a wordless graphic novel The Arrival and Rules of Summer, were recently ranked in the BBC's top 100 children's books of all time.

title.children: His books are loved by kids worldwide, but Shaun Tan says he's not a children's creator

image.altText: A For Sale sign sits on a vacant block of land in Broome, red earth, blue skies.

items.synopsis: The Shire of Broome will spend millions on the construction of four new houses for its key workers as staff members leave the organisation due to low rental stock.

title.children: Broome Shire commits $3 million to new houses for workers amid Kimberley's accommodation crisis

image.altText: A woman smiling while wearing a silky red dress.

items.synopsis: As a study reveals that non-disabled people are reluctant to date people with a disability, these women say they just want to be seen for who they are.

title.children: Dating with a disability is tough. But Jerusha says things can quickly get 'nasty' on dating apps

image.altText: A man in a black polo stands, looking at a woman in a red shirt with a medal around her neck

items.synopsis: Luis Rubiales has come in for a storm of criticism and calls for his resignation over his behaviour during and after Spain's Women's World Cup triumph in Sydney.

title.children: Spanish soccer chief claims 'unprecedented lynching' as government begins move to oust him

image.altText: Man in a blue shirt shares a chair with a woman with black hair

items.synopsis: Ex-mayor of defunct Hurstville City Council Philip Sansom said he had been "very surprised" to hear the ICAC had found he engaged in serious corrupt conduct and he was considering his legal options.

title.children: Former mayor 'very surprised' ICAC considered accepting flights from a developer corrupt behaviour

image.altText: Rudy Giuliani

items.synopsis: Donald Trump's former lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, pleads not guilty to Georgia charges that accuse him of trying to illegally overturn the results of the 2020 election in the state.

title.children: Trump ally Giuliani pleads not guilty to Georgia election fraud case

items.synopsis: When Singapore police raided a suspected money laundering ring last month, they seized property and assets including a collection of about 60 colourful, mostly plastic figurines in the shape of a pot-bellied bear.

title.children: Bearbricks are 'the sweet spot' for criminals looking to launder money, experts say

image.altText: A graphic of Australia showing percentages in blue in each state

items.synopsis: Skyrocketing house prices and mortgage rate increases have dragged housing affordability to its lowest level in three decades, according to new data from real estate analysts PropTrack.

title.children: Housing affordability at lowest level in 30 years, data shows

image.altText: A man looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: While Yevgeny Prigozhin hogged the limelight, Wagner's founder Dmitry Utkin called shots in the shadows — in 2021, he broke the group's golden rule and lawyers saw their chance.

title.children: A terrifying man went down on Prigozhin's plane. In death, Dmitry Utkin's crimes are emerging

image.altText: Composite image of Ruby Franke and police outside a home

items.synopsis: Police reports say Ruby Franke's child appeared "emaciated and malnourished" when they knocked on a neighbour's door asking for food and water.

title.children: Former YouTuber charged with aggravated abuse after child escapes through window

image.altText: A large yellow diamond-shaped sign showing a kangaroos for the next 6 km

items.synopsis: Scattered across the country are iconic yellow diamonds with the silhouette of a native (and some feral) animals. Many of these signs don't have any words on them, yet drivers and the public understand what they represent. But that doesn't mean we act on it.

title.children: Kangaroos next 6km? There's a good reason 'wildlife ahead' signs don't work

image.altText: Male tennis player in a redm white, blue top, plays a two-handed backhand shot.

items.synopsis: Australian wildcard Rinky Hijikata makes the fourth round of a grand slam for the first time in his career.

title.children: Aussie wildcard Rinky moves into the last 16 with impressive US Open win

image.altText: Mark Tamhane sits on a couch holding two young children. A third child, sitting separately on the couch, smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: I'm the stay-at-home dad who left full-time work to better look after my young family.

title.children: It was impossible to juggle full-time work with caring for my children. So I stopped

image.altText: Plumes of smoke seen erupting from a field where mine defences were breached.

items.synopsis: Ukraine has made "some notable progress" in its counteroffensive against Russian forces in the southern Zaporizhzhia region, the US government says.

title.children: Ukrainian army pierces through 'first line' of Russian defences in the south-east

image.altText: Flowers placed on a wooden post, grass patch ahead, a white truck whizzes past a give way/look right sign.

items.synopsis: Residents of a small Victorian country town say the intersection where two couples lost their lives is dangerous at the best of times and can be even more so for people not familiar with the area.

title.children: Shocked town coming to terms with heartbreaking crash that left two couples dead

image.altText: Teagan Ferguson in a wheelchair

items.synopsis: A West Australian man, who was jailed almost two decades ago for causing catastrophic injuries to his young daughter, has been jailed again for his actions — this time for causing her death.

title.children: Father jailed for causing catastrophic injuries to two-year-old daughter that led to her death 15 years later

image.altText: A close up picture of a blonde woman smiling

items.synopsis: Paul Cannon will spend at least 19 years behind bars for the brutal stabbing of his ex-wife Lynne in what the prosecutor described as an act arising out of festering selfishness and jealousy after he learned she had begun a new relationship.

title.children: Applause as 'coward' who murdered ex-wife out of jealousy sentenced to life in prison

image.altText: Composite picture of Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle (left) and Andrew Forrest (right).

items.synopsis: Billionaire mining magnate Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Metals Group loses another of its top executives, as former Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle quits after 18 months at the company.

title.children: Exodus at Andrew Forrest's FMG continues as third top executive departs in a week

image.altText: An empty platform in the middle of nowhere, trees around, dusk.

items.synopsis: A WA MP and Kalgoorlie-Boulder mayor have criticised the state government for dragging its feet on a feasibility study to realign rail around the Super Pit gold mine, which could lead to the development of an intermodal freight facility.

title.children: Delays around $2.5m study into proposed rail realignment case of 'bureaucracy gone crazy'

image.altText: Virginia Trioli smiles while in a radio studio.

items.synopsis: A radio community is a living, thriving, wriggling, combative, remarkable thing. As I prepare to step down I will not miss the early starts. But I know I will not find the kind of conversations and connection to an audience I have had in radio more than anywhere else, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: In four short years it feels like everything has changed — but one thing is constant

image.altText: A skier wearing a purple outfit makes their way across the snow.

items.synopsis: Victoria records one of its worst seasons for natural snowfalls, with record low depths observed in August, and a winter that goes down as the equal third mildest since records began in 1855.

title.children: Despite a strong start, winter was a bust on Victoria's ski fields

image.altText: a woman in a hospital bed overcome with emotion as she holds her newborn

items.synopsis: Almost immediately after an emergency C-section, Adrianna Contoleon was in theatre again — this time for brain surgery.

title.children: 'We wanted to share our love with a child': Mum with spina bifida undergoes multiple surgeries for parenthood dream

image.altText: Objects on the wreck may help identify it

items.synopsis: Detailed 3D maps of the bottom of the Swan River lead maritime archaeologists to a sunken barge in the heart of Perth that has lain unexplored for many years.

title.children: Search for 'lumps and bumps' in Perth's Swan River leads to surprise shipwreck find

image.altText: An older woman in her 40s and a young teenage girl smile and pose for the camera.

items.synopsis: After undergoing surgery that was life-saving but also life-changing, Alice Colgrave agreed to a photo shoot that made her see herself in a new, powerful and positive light.

title.children: Mum's 'flat and fabulous beauty' captured in photo after life-saving mastectomy

image.altText: Two Tasmanian devils relaxing.

items.synopsis: An insidious cancer has ravaged Tasmanian devil populations in recent decades but researchers are now optimistic devil numbers can bounce back.

title.children: It's hard, long and sometimes stinky work, but this marathon effort may have found hope for Tasmanian devils

image.altText: A group of Matildas players and coaches form a heart on the pitch as they talk after a big match.

items.synopsis: The Matildas finished fourth at the World Cup, but if you didn't realise this was about more than the final result, you'd have to have an extremely dim understanding of the human condition.

title.children: Think the Matildas don't deserve a statue for World Cup exploits? Maybe your threshold for statues could change

image.altText: A drawing of dozens of superheroes

items.synopsis: While Batman fought the Joker, the X-Men were fighting prejudice. And while they've haven't always done it perfectly, fans say X-Men comics have been a place "where anyone can see themselves".

title.children: For 60 years, X-Men comics have tackled themes of racism, homophobia, anti-Semitism and more

image.altText: A person in a dark suit jacket looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: More than two decades after the Spin Dragon disaster, and nine years after another accident at the same show claimed the life of an eight-year-old girl, this Adelaide mum is alarmed by an apparent lack of amusement ride safety reform.

title.children: Sarah survived a show ride accident. She finds it 'hard to fathom' show ride safety reform is still in the works

image.altText: A wooden board placed in a school garden reads, 'Our students grow, harvest and learn in this garden'

items.synopsis: Australian chef Stephanie Alexander says "making vegetables the hero of the dish" is the best way to make kids love healthy meals. And her new book, Fresh is has over 120 recipes to do just that.

title.children: Culinary star Stephanie Alexander on 'making vegetables the hero of the dish'
